questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 1:1-28 aloud, focusing on Hannah's silent weeping and her prayer in verses 15-17.
tips: Notice the contrast between Hannah's silent distress (v.12) and her prayer (v.15-17)
Pay attention to the phrase 'my heart is poured out' (v.15) and the vow in v.11-12
Listen for the emotional shift from despair to hope (v.18-28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who is involved, what happens, where it occurs, and why it matters in 1 Samuel 1.
tips: Elkanah and his two wives: Hannah (barren) and Peninnah (has children)
Hannah's silent weeping at Shiloh temple (v.1-10)
Hannah's vow to dedicate her son to the LORD as a Nazirite (v.11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hannah's silent prayer (v.15-17), her vow (v.11-12), or Eli's blessing (v.17).
tips: Hannah's silent prayer shows deep spiritual distress and reliance on God
The vow demonstrates complete surrender to God's will for her son
Eli's blessing highlights God's faithfulness to Hannah's prayer

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel about prayer and faith through Hannah's story?
tips: God answers prayers of the heart even in difficult circumstances
True faith involves surrendering children (or blessings) to God's service
This story foreshadows the future of the kingdom through Samuel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The silent prayer, the meaning of 'Nazirite', or why Eli thought Hannah was drunk?
tips: Silent prayer was common in ancient Israel for distressed women to avoid being heard by others
A Nazirite was a person dedicated to God for life with specific restrictions (no wine, no hair cutting) and often for special service
Eli mistook Hannah's distress for drunkenness due to the emotional state in the temple setting

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Hannah's example of prayer and surrender in your life this week?
tips: Write down a specific prayer for a situation where you feel God is not responding
Make a small vow to dedicate something (like time or a habit) to God this week
Practice speaking your prayer quietly, as Hannah did, to deepen your relationship with God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for answering prayers and ask for the courage to make vows of surrender.
tips: Thank God for the power of prayer in your life
Ask for strength to trust God when you feel barren or without provision
Pray for the gift of a child (or any blessing) that you can dedicate to God's service

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 2:1-17 aloud, focusing on Hannah's song (verses 1-10) and the story of Eli's sons (verses 11-17).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' in Hannah's song (v.1, v.5, v.7)
Pay attention to the contrast between Hannah's praise and Eli's corruption
Hannah's phrase 'He will give strength to His king' (v.7) is a prophecy about Christ

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters in the context of 1 Samuel 2.
tips: Hannah's song of praise to God (v.1-10)
Eli's sons Hophni and Phinehas abusing sacrifices (v.11-13)
Eli's weak rebuke and the prophecy of judgment (v.14-17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hannah's song (v.1-10), Eli's corruption (v.11-13), or the prophecy of the faithful priest (v.14-17)?
tips: Hannah's declaration: 'My heart rejoices in the LORD' (v.1) shows deep joy in God despite her circumstances
The phrase 'the adversaries of the LORD shall be shattered' (v.9) is a powerful promise of God's justice
The prophecy that God will raise up a faithful priest (v.17) points to a future hope

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel about God's character and their situation through this passage?
tips: The contrast between God's faithfulness and human corruption
God's promise of a future king and priest who will uphold His covenant
The need for Israel to turn to God and His righteous rule

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Hannah's song, the nature of Eli's corruption, or the prophecy of judgment?
tips: Hannah's song is a prophetic declaration that looks forward to Christ (the anointed king) - it's not just personal praise but a prediction
Eli's sons are described as 'worthless' (v.11) but they were priests in the tabernacle, so their corruption is a deep sin against God's covenant
The phrase 'God will raise up a faithful priest' (v.17) refers to Samuel, who will replace Eli's line

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does Hannah's song challenge us to trust God's provision in our current situation?
tips: Consider a time when you felt powerless but God was working (like Hannah's situation)
Practice gratitude for God's promises even when circumstances are hard
Ask God to help you be like the faithful priest He will raise up

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His faithfulness in the midst of corruption and hope in His promised king.
tips: Thank God for His song of praise that exalts Him even in our circumstances
Pray for courage to stand against corruption in the church
Ask God to raise up faithful leaders in your life and community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 5:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the descriptions of Dagon's death and the immediate reactions of the Philistines.
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'the ark of the Lord' (v1, v2, v3) shows the Philistines' fear and reverence for the ark
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the Philistines' actions: first setting Dagon up again, then his gruesome state the next morning
The phrase 'God's hand is heavy' (v8) is a key expression of divine judgment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Philistines) does WHAT (places the ark in Dagon's temple at Ashdod), WHERE (Ashdod), and WHY (to avoid the ark's judgment). Include the consequences: Dagon's death, the plague, and the demand to send the ark away.
tips: Include the event of Dagon falling face down and being set up again
Note the specific affliction: tumors and a plague of mice
Mention the immediate reaction: the people of Ashdod demand to send the ark away

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Dagon's fall (v3-4), the next morning's condition (v6-7), or the phrase 'God's hand is heavy' (v8).
tips: Dagon's body being cut off shows the complete defeat of a false god
The phrase 'God's hand is heavy' (v8) is a powerful image of divine judgment that the Philistines cannot ignore
The immediate reaction of the people to the plague (v9-10) shows the severity of the judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about God's honor and the consequences of hosting the ark without proper reverence?
tips: The passage shows that the Philistines' attempt to honor the ark with their idol (Dagon) leads to their downfall
Samuel's purpose was to demonstrate that God's presence (the ark) must be honored with proper worship, not mixed with idolatry
This event foreshadows the need for the Israelites to be careful with the ark's placement and the consequences of idolatry

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The meaning of 'God's hand is heavy', why Dagon's head and hands were cut off, and the significance of the mice plague.
tips: 'God's hand is heavy' (v8) is a metaphor for divine judgment that is overwhelming and devastating
Dagon's head and hands being cut off (v7) symbolizes the complete destruction of the idol that the Philistines had set up
The plague of mice (v9) is a sign of divine judgment that affects the land and the people, indicating God's wrath

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the passage challenge you to handle God's presence in your life? What area of your life needs to be 'sent away' like the ark was sent from Ashdod?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding onto something that is not God (like a false god of your own making)
Think about what you might need to 'send away' to make space for God's presence
Pray for the courage to let go of what is not God and trust Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment when we try to honor Him with idols. Ask for the strength to honor Him properly.
tips: Thank God that He is the true God and no false god can stand before Him
Pray for the courage to send away the idols in your life
Ask God to help you avoid the consequences of idolatry by keeping His presence in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 8:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the elders' demand for a king and the LORD's warning about the burdens of kingship.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'We want a king' (v.1, 20)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from the elders' urgency to the LORD's stern warning (v.12-18)
Note the specific burdens: taking sons for armies, daughters for service, best fields, and a tenth of everything (v.16-17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Israel's elders) is demanding, WHAT (a king to judge them like other nations), WHERE (in the land of Israel), and WHY (they are tired of judges and want a human ruler like the nations).
tips: Include the context that Samuel's sons were corrupt (v.3-5)
Note the people's demand: 'appoint us a king to judge us like all the nations' (v.1)
Describe the outcome: the LORD grants their request but warns of heavy burdens (v.22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the elders' demand (v.1-2), the LORD's warning (v.12-18), or the people's insistence (v.20)?
tips: The elders' demand: 'We want a king' (v.1) - shows their desperation for a solution to their problems
The LORD's warning: 'he will take your sons for his army, daughters for his service, best fields, a tenth of everything' (v.16-17) - the specific burdens that the people might not have considered
The people's insistence: 'No! We want a king!' (v.20) - demonstrates their strong determination despite the warnings

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about the consequences of demanding a human king?
tips: Samuel's role as the last judge and his sons' corruption (v.3-5) shows that the people are turning away from God as king
The warning about the burdens of kingship (v.12-18) is a call to be cautious about the cost of having a human ruler
This passage foreshadows the need for the true King (Christ) who will not take the people's possessions but will provide for them

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The LORD's statement about not rejecting God but Him from being king? The heavy burdens of kingship? The historical context of Israel's idolatry?
tips: 'They have not rejected you [Samuel] but Me [God] from being king' (v.7) means they are not rejecting the human judge (Samuel) but God as the true king
A 'tenth of everything' (v.17) was a heavy tax that would affect the poor and the land, showing the burden of kingship
'Forsaking Me and serving other gods' (v.10) refers to Israel's history of turning away from God to worship other gods (e.g., Baal, Moloch) since the Exodus

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid the pitfalls of following a human leader instead of God? Identify one area where you might be taking a 'tenth' (time, money, attention) for a human purpose and ask God to redirect it.
tips: Reflect on the warning about the king taking your sons and daughters for service: How might this play out in your life?
This week, identify one area where you might be giving up your resources for a human leader (e.g., time, money) and ask God to use it for His purposes
Ask God to help you choose the true king (Christ) over human rulers

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of Israel rejecting God as king and the consequences of that rejection.
tips: Thank God for His warning about the burdens of kingship (so we don't follow the same pattern)
Ask for wisdom to not follow human leaders when God is the true king
Pray for the courage to reject the temptation to be like the nations (v.10) and to choose God as king

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 9:1-16 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Samuel and Saul (verses 10-12).
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'the LORD says' (v.10, 12)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Samuel's confidence and Saul's awe
Notice the phrase 'Do not worry about the donkeys—they have been found' (v.12) as a sign of God's provision

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Kish, Saul, Samuel), WHAT (Saul's search for lost donkeys, God's appointment of Saul as future king), WHERE (near Zuph), and WHY (to save Israel from Philistines) in 1 Samuel 9.
tips: Include that Saul is described as 'tall and handsome, head and shoulders above everyone' (v.2)
Note that Samuel had been told by God to anoint a leader from Benjamin (v.15)
Mention that Samuel invites Saul to eat and gives him the honored seat and choice portion (v.11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Saul's impressive appearance (v.2), God's immediate recognition (v.10), or Samuel's hospitality (v.11-12)?
tips: Saul's description as 'tall and handsome, head and shoulders above everyone' (v.2) shows God's choice of an outwardly impressive leader
Samuel's declaration 'this is the man' (v.10) is a powerful moment of divine appointment
The phrase 'Do not worry about the donkeys—they have been found' (v.12) shows God's provision and care

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about God's choice of Saul?
tips: Samuel was showing that God's choice of leadership is not based on human merit but on divine appointment
This passage sets up the contrast between Saul's outward appearance and the future king (David) who is chosen by God's heart
The theme of divine appointment foreshadows Christ, who is chosen by God's heart and not by outward appearance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the donkeys, why God chose Saul, and the significance of Samuel's anointing?
tips: The donkeys being lost and then found (v.12) is a sign of God's provision but also a test of Saul's trust
Saul's outward appearance (v.2) is used by God, but later he fails because he lacks the inner heart of David
Samuel's anointing (v.16) is a divine act that sets Saul as the future king, but it's a temporary choice until God's heart is fully revealed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage this week? Focus on God's appointment of leaders and trusting in His choice even when you don't see the full picture.
tips: Consider a situation where you feel God has chosen someone else for a role
Practice stepping out in obedience to God's appointment, even if it's not obvious
Ask God to help you see the bigger picture and trust His choice

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereign choice of leaders and ask for the wisdom to trust in His appointment.
tips: Thank God that He chooses leaders who are not perfect but are set apart by His will
Pray for courage to trust God's choice even when it's difficult
Ask God to reveal the inner heart of people and to guide your choices

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 10:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Samuel and the men at the oak of Tabor (v.4) and the people's reaction at Mizpah (v.20-21).
tips: Notice the phrase 'the LORD has anointed you' (v.1) repeated as a declaration of God's choice
Pay attention to the signs: meeting men near Rachel's tomb (v.3), the bread at the oak of Tabor (v.4), and the prophetic experience at Gibeah (v.5)
The emotional shift from awe (v.19) to the people's shout: 'Long live the king!' (v.20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Samuel, Saul, the people of Israel) does WHAT (anoints Saul and gives signs), WHERE (near Rachel's tomb, at the oak of Tabor, at Gibeah, and Mizpah), and WHY (to confirm God's choice of a king for Israel).
tips: Include the three signs that Saul experiences: men near Rachel's tomb, bread at the oak of Tabor, and the Spirit rushing at Gibeah
Note that the people choose Saul by lot at Mizpah (v.17-18) and proclaim him king (v.20-21)
Saul's initial response is to hold his peace when criticized (v.21)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the anointing with oil (v.1-2), the Spirit rushing upon Saul at Gibeah (v.5), or Saul's prophesying among the prophets (v.19-20).
tips: The oil anointing (v.1) is a powerful symbol of God's choice and the beginning of Saul's kingship
The Spirit rushing upon Saul (v.5) shows a temporary but dramatic manifestation of God's power, different from Christ's permanent Spirit
Saul's prophesying (v.19-20) is a sign of his anointing and the people's astonishment (v.20) highlights God's work

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about God's choice of a king?
tips: The anointing is a sign of God's direct choice and authority (not human election)
The signs were to confirm that the anointed one is God's chosen leader (to avoid false claims)
This passage foreshadows Christ as the true anointed one (Messiah) whose reign never fails and whose Spirit transforms His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The signs for Saul, the meaning of 'spirit rushing', and why the people chose Saul by lot.
tips: The signs (v.3-5) are not magical but divine confirmations that God has chosen Saul (to be fulfilled in the context of the time)
'Spirit rushing' (v.5) is a temporary empowerment for prophetic activity (as in the Old Testament), not the same as the permanent indwelling of the Holy Spirit in Christ
Choosing by lot (v.17-18) was a way to ensure the LORD's choice, avoiding human bias in leadership

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be anointed by the Holy Spirit in your life this week? Consider the signs that God may send to confirm your calling.
tips: Identify one area where you need to be 'anointed' by the Holy Spirit (e.g., in your service, relationships, or prayer)
Seek God's signs of confirmation in your life (like the signs for Saul) to know His purpose
Practice holding your peace when criticized (v.21) by trusting God's anointing

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for anointing you with His Spirit and ask for the courage to be like Saul in the early stages of your calling.
tips: Thank God for the Holy Spirit's anointing (like the oil in v.1)
Pray for the Spirit to rush upon you in your current season (v.5)
Ask God to help you hold your peace when criticized (v.21) and trust His signs

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 11:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from despair to victory.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the Spirit of God rushed upon him' (v.8) shows sudden divine intervention
Pay attention to the repetition of 'oxen' (v.9) as a symbol of the people's resources
The phrase 'the LORD has given salvation' (v.12) is a key declaration of God's active role

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Jabesh-gilead and Saul), WHAT (the Ammonite threat and Saul's response), WHERE (Jabesh-gilead and Gibeah), and WHY (to avoid disgrace and secure Israel's deliverance).
tips: Include the offer to serve Nahash (v.3) and the demand for gouging eyes (v.4)
Note Saul's immediate action: cutting oxen and sending them as a warning (v.9)
Describe the assembly of 330,000 and the victory at dawn (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the people's despair (v.7), Saul's anger (v.8), or the refusal to kill (v.12).
tips: Saul's anger and the Spirit's action (v.8) shows divine empowerment in crisis
The 330,000 assembling (v.10) demonstrates the power of unity in response to God's call
Saul's mercy (v.12) - refusing to kill those who questioned his leadership - shows the heart of God's deliverance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: Samuel was showing that God's deliverance comes through the Spirit-empowered leadership of Saul, and that the people must respond with unity and trust in God's plan
This passage emphasizes that God's mercy and victory are not earned by human strength but by faith in Him
It foreshadows how God will deliver His people from threats and establish a kingdom of peace

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The demand for gouging eyes, the Spirit of God rushing upon Saul, and the oxen as a sign of punishment.
tips: The demand to gouge eyes was a cultural practice of disgrace (as in ancient Near Eastern practices) to shame the people
The Spirit 'rushing upon Saul' (v.8) is a divine empowerment, not mere anger; it shows God's direct involvement in the crisis
The oxen were a symbol of the people's resources and the severity of the punishment (v.9) - if you don't follow Saul, your oxen will be destroyed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This passage shows the power of unity and mercy in response to crisis. What situation requires you to rally others in faith and trust like Saul did this week?
tips: Consider a challenge where you need to act quickly and decisively
Think about how you can show mercy to others who might be questioning your leadership
Practice being the 'Saul' who acts with divine empowerment in the face of crisis

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for delivering us from threats and showing mercy in victory.
tips: Thank God for the Spirit-empowered response to crisis
Pray for courage to act in faith when others are fearful
Ask God to give mercy to those in crisis and to prevent us from holding grudges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 13:1-14 aloud, focusing on Saul's panic when the people scatter (v. 2-3) and his immediate sacrifice (v. 10-11).
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'the LORD' in verses 10-14
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Saul's panic (v. 3: 'Saul said to his men, I have done foolishly')
Listen for the phrase 'I will not wait' in verse 10

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Saul) is acting, WHAT (offering the burnt sacrifice), WHERE (Gilgal), and WHY (because he panicked when the people scattered) in 1 Samuel 13.
tips: Include the event of the people scattering and Saul's panic (v. 2-3)
Note that Saul acted without waiting for Samuel to arrive (v. 10-11)
Mention the consequence: Samuel's confrontation (v. 13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Saul's panic (v. 3), his excuse (v. 13), or Samuel's pronouncement (v. 13-14).
tips: Saul's panic shows his fear of failure and his desire for control
The phrase 'I have done foolishly' (v. 13) reveals his self-awareness but also his failure to repent
Samuel's pronouncement 'the LORD has sought a man after His own heart' (v. 14) is a promise of a future king who will be obedient

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about the danger of acting without proper authority and the need for obedience to God's commands?
tips: Samuel warns that Saul's usurpation of the priestly role (which is God's office) shows a breakdown in the covenant
The passage emphasizes that God's chosen king must be obedient to His commands (the sacrifice was a sign of covenant)
The consequence: Saul's kingdom will not continue because he did not keep God's command

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The urgency of Saul's action, the phrase 'the LORD has sought a man after His own heart', and the consequence of the kingdom not continuing.
tips: In ancient Israel, the priest was the only one who could offer sacrifices (Leviticus 1:3-4), so Saul acting without the priest was a grave violation
'Sought a man after His own heart' means God is actively looking for a leader who is in perfect alignment with His will (like David), not Saul
The kingdom not continuing refers to the fact that Saul's reign would end and God would choose a new king (David) who would be obedient

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you wait for God's timing and the right person instead of acting prematurely in your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are rushing to act without waiting for the right time (e.g., decisions in your work or family)
Ask God to help you pause and seek His guidance before taking action
Pray for the strength to follow Samuel's example of waiting for God's command

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for warning us about acting without proper authority. Ask for the strength to wait for God's timing and for the right person to lead in your decisions.
tips: Thank God that He provides a way for us to act in obedience (as in the example of David)
Pray for courage to wait for God's timing in difficult situations
Ask God to help you recognize when you are acting prematurely and to repent

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 15:1-31 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from Saul's confidence to his despair.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (5 times in the chapter) to emphasize God's role
Pay attention to the contrast between Saul's words (v.12) and Samuel's response (v.15)
Listen for the tearing of the robe (v.29) as a symbol of the broken relationship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Saul) is commanded to do WHAT (utterly destroy Amalek) WHERE (Amalek's territory) and WHY (to follow God's command).
tips: Include how Saul spared King Agag and the best livestock
Note Samuel's grief and the tearing of the robe (v.29)
Describe the immediate rejection of Saul as king and the execution of Agag (v.30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Saul's claim of obedience (v.12), Samuel's thundering response (v.15), or the tearing of the robe (v.29).
tips: Saul's claim: 'I have performed the LORD's command' (v.12) shows his pride and misunderstanding
Samuel's response: 'Does the LORD delight in sacrifices as in obeying?' (v.15) is a direct challenge to Saul's pride
The tearing of the robe (v.29) symbolizes the severance of Saul's kingship and his broken relationship with God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about the nature of true kingship and obedience?
tips: Samuel emphasizes that obedience to God's command (total destruction) is more important than ritual sacrifices
The kingdom of Israel is conditional on following God's word, not on human merit
This passage shows that God's covenant with Israel is based on obedience, not on the king's ability to maintain the kingdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The partial obedience of Saul, the meaning of 'sacrifice' in this context, or the immediate rejection of Saul?
tips: In ancient Israel, kings were expected to be God's representatives; Saul's failure to destroy everything shows he was not truly following God
The phrase 'sacrifice' here (v.15) refers to ritual offerings, but Samuel is saying obedience is a better 'sacrifice'
The execution of Agag by Samuel (v.30) shows that God's judgment is carried out by His chosen representatives

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge you to be more obedient in your daily life? Focus on the theme of complete obedience versus partial obedience.
tips: Consider a situation where you've been 'partial' (e.g., not doing the full command) and what it cost you
Ask God to help you see when you are 'sparing' something that God has commanded to be destroyed (e.g., sin, ungodly habits)
Commit to one step of complete obedience this week, even if it's small

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His holiness and ask for help to obey completely.
tips: Thank God for rejecting partial obedience and calling for total surrender
Pray for the courage to follow God's commands even when it's difficult
Ask God to help you see when you are 'sparing' something that needs to be destroyed (e.g., sin, pride)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 16:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Samuel's initial fear (v.2) and God's confidence (v.3).
tips: Notice the phrase 'the LORD looks on the heart' (v.7) and how Samuel initially focuses on appearance (v.6)
Pay attention to the description of David: 'ruddy, with beautiful eyes, and handsome' (v.12) versus Eliab's 'impressive appearance' (v.11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Samuel and Jesse's sons), WHAT (God commands Samuel to anoint a king from Jesse's sons), WHERE (Bethlehem), and WHY (God chooses the one with a heart for Him, not appearance).
tips: Include the key event: Samuel anoints David (v.14-16)
Note that the Spirit of the LORD rushes upon David immediately after anointing (v.16)
The contrast: Saul is tormented by a harmful spirit (v.19-23) while David is anointed

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's description (v.11-13), the anointing (v.14-16), or the immediate effect on David (v.16).
tips: David's simple description as a shepherd boy (v.12) shows humility and God's focus on the heart
The phrase 'the Spirit of the LORD rushes upon David' (v.16) indicates a divine empowerment that was immediate and powerful
The contrast between Samuel's initial fear (v.2) and God's confidence (v.3) highlights God's sovereignty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about God's choice of leaders?
tips: God chooses leaders based on the heart, not external appearances or status
This passage shows that God's anointing brings the Holy Spirit's presence and power
It foreshadows Christ, the Good Shepherd, who is anointed by the Holy Spirit and chooses His sheep

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'the LORD looks on the heart' (v.7), the anointing process, or Saul's suffering?
tips: In ancient Israel, 'heart' (leb) meant the inner self, including intentions and character, not just physical heart
The anointing was a ritual sign of God's appointment, but the 'Spirit rushing' was a unique event indicating divine empowerment
Saul's suffering was due to the departure of the Spirit (v.19), which was a consequence of his failure to follow God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In what situation this week are you being called to choose based on heart rather than appearance?
tips: Consider a leadership role or relationship where you might be influenced by appearance
How can you cultivate a heart that seeks God's perspective?
Pray for the courage to follow God's call even when it's not obvious (like David)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Ask God to help you look for the heart in others and in yourself.
tips: Thank God for the anointing of the Holy Spirit in your life
Pray for the courage to follow God's call in your life
Ask God to reveal the heart of others that might need His grace

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 17:1-54 aloud, focusing on the tension between Goliath's challenge and David's response.
tips: Notice the contrast in David's declaration: 'I come in the name of the LORD of hosts' (v. 36) versus Goliath's arrogance
Pay attention to the emotional shift from fear (v. 32-33) to David's confidence (v. 35-36)
Listen for the repetition of 'the LORD will deliver me' (v. 36) as a declaration of faith

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is challenged, what happens, where it occurs, and why it matters for Israel.
tips: Include Goliath's challenge (v. 32-34) and David's refusal of Saul's armor (v. 38-40)
Note that David had previously killed lions and bears (v. 39) and that he slings a stone (v. 49)
Describe how David cuts off Goliath's head with his own sword (v. 50) and the Philistines flee (v. 51)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out most? Consider: David's declaration (v. 36), the stone hitting Goliath's forehead (v. 49), or David cutting off the head (v. 50)?
tips: David's declaration: 'You come with sword and spear; I come in the name of the LORD of hosts' shows his trust in God's power
The stone hitting Goliath's forehead (v. 49) is a sudden, decisive act that breaks the cycle of violence
David cutting off Goliath's head with his own sword (v. 50) demonstrates that victory comes through God's provision, not human strength

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about God's victory through the unlikely?
tips: Samuel intended to show that God's power is not in human strength but in faith and trust
This passage foreshadows Christ defeating Satan and the ultimate victory of God's kingdom
It emphasizes that the battle belongs to the LORD (v. 47) and that victory is won through faith, not military might

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider: why David refused armor, the meaning of 'uncircumcised', and the battle context.
tips: The term 'uncircumcised' (v. 26) refers to non-Israelites (the Philistines) and highlights David's awareness of the spiritual divide
David's refusal of armor (v. 38) shows his faith that God's power is in the spirit, not physical strength
Goliath's challenge (v. 32-34) is a test of Israel's confidence in God, which Saul fails to address

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply David's faith in God's provision to a current situation?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel overwhelmed by a 'Goliath' (a challenge) and trust God to deliver
Practice being 'David' by using your God-given strengths (like your mind, your hands) in faith
Ask God to help you trust His provision in a specific area this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His victory over enemies and ask for courage to trust Him.
tips: Thank God that He provides victory through the unlikely
Pray for the courage to face challenges with faith, like David
Ask God to help you cut off the 'Goliath' in your life with the sword of the Spirit

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 18:1-39 aloud, paying attention to the emotional contrast between Jonathan's love for David and Saul's growing jealousy.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'David is a man of war' (v. 2) and how Jonathan's actions (giving his robe, armor, etc.) contrast with Saul's attempts to kill David
Pay attention to the women's song in verses 6-7: 'Saul has slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Jonathan's covenant with David (v. 4): giving his robe, armor, sword, bow, and belt
Note the Philistine victory and the women's song (v. 6-7) that triggers Saul's jealousy
Highlight the failed attempts on David's life (v. 10-11) and the resolution with Michal (v. 28-39)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jonathan's covenant love (v. 4), the women's song (v. 6-7), or David's willingness to bring 200 foreskins (v. 30)?
tips: Jonathan's declaration 'my soul is knit to David's' (v. 3) shows a bond deeper than blood and is a powerful example of covenant love
The women's song (v. 6-7) highlights the contrast in military success that becomes the catalyst for Saul's jealousy
David's willingness to bring 200 foreskins (double the required amount) demonstrates his courage and trust in God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that true leadership (Saul) is often undermined by jealousy and that God's chosen ones (David) are set apart by divine favor
The covenant between Jonathan and David prefigures the new covenant in Christ, where believers are knit together in love

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The title 'David is a man of war', the bride price of 100 Philistine foreskins, or why Jonathan gives his possessions to David?
tips: In ancient Israel, a 'man of war' (Hebrew: shahar) was a warrior who led armies; this was a title given to David early in his life
Foreskins were used in some ancient Near Eastern cultures as a sign of sacrifice or a ritual payment, but the exact practice here is not well-documented
Jonathan's act of giving his possessions to David was a covenant of loyalty, but it was a strategic move that Saul misinterpreted as a threat

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of covenant love from this passage in your life?
tips: This week, identify one person you can 'knit' with through acts of service or genuine care, just as Jonathan did with David
Consider how you can become a 'covenant keeper' in your relationships by showing loyalty and giving of your resources (time, talents) without expectation of return

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of covenant love and jealousy in this passage.
tips: Thank God for the covenant love that exists between believers (like Jonathan and David)
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you see the jealousy in your relationships and to act with the same covenant love
Pray for courage to stand in the presence of God's anointed (like David) without fear of the enemy (Saul)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 19:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jonathan and David in verses 3-7 and Michal's actions in verses 18-20.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'David' (appears 10 times) to see the king's obsession
Pay attention to the emotional shift from Saul's anger to his prophetic moments (v.23-24)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE and WHY in 1 Samuel 19.
tips: Include Jonathan's intercession (v.3-7) and Saul's vow (v.6)
Note David's escape through the window (v.18-20) and the idol deception
Describe Saul's prophetic behavior (v.23-24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jonathan's intercession (v.3-7), Michal's deception (v.18-20), or Saul's prophetic involuntarily (v.23-24)?
tips: Jonathan's words: 'David has not sinned against you; his deeds have benefited you greatly' (v.4) show deep loyalty
Michal's plan with the idol (v.21-22) is a clever but risky deception
Saul's nakedness (v.23-24) as a sign of his broken spirit

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to the Israelites about God and leadership through this passage?
tips: This passage shows the danger of unjust kingship and the cost of faithful service
It contrasts the righteous king (David) with the unrighteous one (Saul) who fails to recognize God's work
The prophetic outbursts of Saul (v.23-24) indicate the spiritual consequences of sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The idol in the bed (v.21), why Saul hurls his spear (v.13), or the prophetic behavior (v.23-24)?
tips: The household idol (v.21) is a Canaanite practice, which Michal uses to deceive Saul's men
Saul's 'evil spirit' (v.13) is likely a divine punishment for his sin against David
Saul's prophetic utterances (v.23-24) are involuntary and show his spiritual state

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can we apply this to our lives? Consider the theme of escape from danger or deception.
tips: When you feel threatened by a situation, ask: 'Is there a way to escape without causing harm?' (like Michal's plan)
Practice the courage of Jonathan: stand up for the innocent even when it's risky
Reflect on how God might be your 'prophet' in your current situation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of being hunted by the king you serve (like David) or the danger of leadership.
tips: Thank God for protecting us from the unrighteousness of leaders
Ask for the courage to be like Jonathan and stand for the innocent
Pray that we don't become the 'Sauls' who ignore God's work

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 20:1-42 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tension in David's plea and Jonathan's response.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD be between us' (v.42)
Pay attention to the arrow signals (v.34-35) as a sign of trust
Listen for the emotional shift from David's fear (v.1-3) to the covenant promise (v.42)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY David and Jonathan are doing this.
tips: David flees to Jonathan after Saul seeks his life (v.1-3)
They devise a plan for the new moon feast to test Saul's intentions (v.18-20)
Jonathan uses arrow signals to communicate danger without confrontation (v.34-35)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jonathan's warning (v.34-35), David's plea (v.1-3), or the covenant (v.42)?
tips: Jonathan's arrow signal: a practical and loving way to test Saul without direct conflict
David's desperate words: 'there is but a step between me and death' (v.3) shows his fear of imminent death
The covenant: 'May the LORD be between you and me, between my descendants and yours forever' (v.42) is a timeless promise

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage shows that true loyalty and covenant relationships are more valuable than political power
It highlights the danger of Saul's obsession with power and the cost of betrayal
This covenant between David and Jonathan prefigures Christ's self-sacrificial love for His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts in this chapter.
tips: The 'arrow signal' (v.34-35): In ancient warfare, arrows were used for communication in emergencies. This shows Jonathan's cleverness and love for David.
Saul's attack on his own son (v.40): This is a shocking act that reveals Saul's complete lack of judgment and his obsession with power.

The covenant for generations (v.42): How does this covenant work in a world of political instability? The author is showing that God can use even the most unlikely relationships to establish a lasting

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the covenant theme to your relationships this week?
tips: Think of a person you have a deep commitment to (like a friend or family member) and commit to being a 'Jonathan' for them in times of danger
Practice the arrow signal: be the one who sends a clear, non-threatening sign of support when you are in a vulnerable situation
Make a promise to someone that will last beyond your current circumstances, like the covenant between Jonathan and David

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the covenant between David and Jonathan and how it reflects God's faithfulness.
tips: Thank God for the covenant that goes beyond human relationships
Pray for strength to be loyal to others even when it's costly
Ask God to help you make a covenant that will last through trials

chapters.chapterTitle: David at Nob; Flees to Gath

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 21:1-22 aloud, focusing on David's dialogue with Ahimelech in verses 1-3 and the description of David's escape in verses 18-22.
tips: Notice David's trembling when Ahimelech asks why he is alone (v.2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the bread of the Presence' (v.3) which is holy bread
Observe the contrast between David's normal life and his current situation (v.18-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is in danger, WHAT he needs, WHERE he goes, and WHY he takes specific items.
tips: Include that David is fleeing from Saul's pursuit
Note that David gets holy bread and Goliath's sword from the temple
Mention Doeg's role as the one who sees David and causes his escape

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's lie about the mission (v.2), the holy bread (v.3-4), Goliath's sword (v.5-6), or David's feigned madness (v.18-22)?
tips: David's lie shows his courage and need for survival
The holy bread is a symbol of God's provision for necessity
Goliath's sword represents the past conflict and David's readiness to fight

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel about the proper response to crisis and God's provision?
tips: The passage shows that God provides for human need (like David's) even when it's outside the usual ceremonial order
It warns about the danger of being known by enemies (like Doeg)
The holy bread and the sword are both tools for survival, but David must hide to avoid death

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The holy bread, why David takes the sword, and Doeg's role?
tips: The 'bread of the Presence' was only for priests to eat; David needed it for his life, showing God's provision for necessity
Goliath's sword was a symbol of the enemy of Israel; David taking it shows his use of past resources for present survival
Doeg was Saul's chief herdsman and was a threat to David, so his presence made David's escape even more urgent

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In your situation, when do you need to trust God to provide for your immediate needs (like the holy bread) rather than following the rules?
tips: Think of a time when you were in a crisis and needed to make a quick decision
How can you be like David and take what you need without being caught by the enemy?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for providing for our needs in times of crisis. Ask for courage to trust Him when it's hard.
tips: Thank God for providing the holy bread (necessity) even when it's not the usual
Pray for the strength to hide from enemies when we are in danger
Ask for the wisdom to know when to take the sword (resources) for survival

chapters.chapterTitle: The Cave of Adullam; Massacre of the Priests

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 22:1-30 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Saul's complaint and the impact of the priest massacre.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the son of Jesse' in Saul's complaint (v. 2) which shows his distrust
Pay attention to the emotional weight of the massacre of 85 priests (v. 26-29)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is gathering the outcasts, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY (Saul's paranoia and David's response).
tips: Include David gathering about 400 men in the cave of Adullam (v. 1-6)
Note Saul's complaint about David's fields (v. 2) and the subsequent massacre at Nob (v. 26-29)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What event or phrase from the passage most resonates with you? Choose 2-3 options.
tips: Saul's complaint: 'will the son of Jesse give you fields?' (v. 2) reflects his paranoia and fear of David's influence
The massacre of 85 priests (v. 26-29) shows the extreme cost of Saul's actions
David's taking responsibility (v. 30) is a powerful example of humility and accountability

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage contrasts David's compassionate leadership with Saul's destructive paranoia
It emphasizes the importance of preserving God's priesthood and the consequences of a king who lacks wisdom
David's taking responsibility for the priests' deaths foreshadows his future role as the king who will uphold God's covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What are the most confusing elements in this passage?
tips: Why did Saul order the massacre of the priests? (He heard that Ahimelech had given David bread and a sword, which he saw as a threat to his authority)
The number 85 is significant because it represents the complete destruction of the priesthood at Nob, a central place of worship
Abᰁathar was the high priest's son and fled to David because he was the only one who survived the massacre

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage to your life this week?
tips: Identify one person in your life who is struggling and reach out to them with compassion
Practice being a place of safety for someone who is feeling overwhelmed
Reflect on how you can be a leader for the outcasts in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of this passage: the danger of paranoia and the need for compassionate leadership.
tips: Thank God for David's compassion and his willingness to gather the outcasts
Pray for courage to be a leader of the outcasts in your life
Ask God to help you avoid the paranoia that leads to destruction

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 25:1-42 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension between David and Nabal.
tips: Notice Nabal's insult: 'Who is David? Many servants break away from masters nowadays!' (v. 25)
Pay attention to Abigail's humble response: 'I bow before you' (v. 28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE and WHEN it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: David's men were shepherds who had protected the sheep of Nabal
Abigail quickly gathered food and went to meet David to prevent bloodshed
Nabal died as a result of God's judgment, and David married Abigail

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Nabal's insult (v. 25), Abigail's wisdom (v. 28-30), or David's mercy (v. 37-39)?
tips: Nabal's words: 'Who is David? Many servants break away from masters nowadays!' (v. 25) reveal his foolishness and lack of understanding of David's standing
Abigail's bowing and taking blame (v. 29-30) show her humility and quick thinking
David's response: 'The LORD has made me the one who will be your deliverer' (v. 39) demonstrates his trust in God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that God's justice is not about human vengeance but about restoring relationships through wisdom
The author emphasizes that God's intervention (like the death of Nabal) is a warning against foolishness and a call for humility
The story foreshadows Christ as the one who brings reconciliation and mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Nabal's death, why David didn't kill him immediately, the significance of Abigail's actions?
tips: Nabal's name means 'fool' (Hebrew: nabal) - this is a direct reference to his foolishness
David's initial plan to kill Nabal was a reaction to insult, but God intervened through Abigail's wisdom
The phrase 'the LORD will strike him dead' (v. 40) is a divine judgment that shows God's control over human actions

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Abigail's wisdom and courage in your life this week?
tips: When you feel angry or tempted to retaliate, ask yourself: 'What would Abigail do?'
Think about a time when you were wronged and how you could have handled it with grace instead of vengeance
Pray for the strength to be a peacemaker when others are foolish, like Abigail was with Nabal

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the theme of wisdom and mercy in this chapter
tips: Thank God for Abigail's example of humility and quick thinking
Ask for the wisdom to avoid Nabal's foolishness in your relationships
Pray that God will use you to be a blessing to others, like David did with Abigail

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 26:1-25 aloud, focusing on David's dialogue with Abishai and Saul's recognition of David.
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (v. 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 14, 17, 20, 22, 23)
Pay attention to the emotional shift: from David's fear (v. 3) to his confidence (v. 4-5) and the tension in Saul's voice (v. 19)
The phrase 'I have sinned; I have played the fool' (v. 21) is a key emotional moment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO does WHAT, WHERE, and WHY.
tips: Include David's scouting and the deep sleep of the camp (v. 2-3)
Note that Saul is the anointed king (v. 5) and David is the anointed of the LORD (v. 4)
David's decision to return Saul's spear and the blessing (v. 21-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's refusal to harm Saul (v. 5), the deep sleep from the LORD (v. 3), or Saul's recognition of David's voice (v. 21).
tips: David's declaration: 'Who can stretch out his hand against the LORD's anointed and be guiltless?' (v. 5) shows his profound understanding of God's sovereignty
The deep sleep from the LORD (v. 3) is a unique sign of divine protection that David uses to his advantage
Saul's admission: 'I have sinned; I have played the fool' (v. 21) reveals his humility and realization of his folly

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel/Nathan/Gad trying to communicate to Israel through this passage about David sparing Saul?
tips: This passage emphasizes that even the anointed king (Saul) can be held accountable by God and that the anointed (David) must act with integrity and faithfulness
It shows that God's anointed (the Messiah) is not to be harmed by the anointed king (Saul) but is to be protected by the LORD
The passage foreshadows Christ, who, despite being anointed (the Messiah), did not harm the anointed (the Father) but entrusted Himself to God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The deep sleep of the camp, why David doesn't kill Saul, the meaning of 'the LORD's anointed' in this context.
tips: The deep sleep (v. 3) is a divine sign that the LORD has protected the camp, which is unusual in a military context
David's refusal to kill Saul (v. 5) is challenging because it shows that even when the anointed king is in danger, the anointed of the LORD (David) must act with restraint and faith
The phrase 'the LORD's anointed' (v. 5) refers to the king of Israel (Saul) and the future Messiah (David) - this duality is central to the passage

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: David's refusal to harm the anointed (Saul) shows that we must trust God's judgment even when we are tempted to act in anger. What situation requires you to trust God's timing and judgment this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel the need to take revenge or act impulsively
Think about how you can choose to step back and trust God's plan, like David did
Practically, set a time to reflect on the situation and ask God for wisdom before acting

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the anointing of His people and the protection He provides. Ask for the strength to resist the urge to act in anger when you feel wronged.
tips: Thank God for the anointing of His people and the protection He provides
Ask for the strength to resist the urge to act in anger when you feel wronged
Pray that God will help you recognize when you are the anointed and when the anointed is in need of protection

chapters.chapterTitle: Saul and the Witch of Endor

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 28:1-20 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of Saul's fear and the sudden appearance of Samuel.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Saul' in the narrative (v. 2, 5, 8, 12)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the LORD has become your enemy' (v. 15) as a shocking declaration
Listen for the contrast between Saul's desperation (v. 3) and Samuel's certainty (v. 15-18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Saul and the witch of Endor), WHAT (Saul seeks Samuel through forbidden means), WHERE (Endor), and WHY (Saul's fear over the Philistine threat and God's silence).
tips: Include Saul's initial fear (v. 2) and his request for a medium (v. 3)
Note the witch's role (v. 10-11) and Samuel's appearance (v. 13)
Describe Samuel's pronouncement about the kingdom being given to David (v. 15-18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Saul's disguise (v. 5-7), Samuel's pronouncement (v. 15), or the immediate consequence (v. 18).
tips: Saul's disguise shows his desperation and the risk he takes to seek God's help
Samuel's words: 'the LORD has become your enemy' (v. 15) is a devastating and unambiguous statement of God's rejection
The consequence: 'Tomorrow you and your sons will be with me' (v. 18) is a direct and immediate call to death

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Samuel trying to communicate to Israel about God's response to disobedience and the consequences of seeking false answers?
tips: The passage shows that God's silence is not abandonment but a call to repentance through proper channels
Saul's failure to obey the command about Amalek (1 Samuel 15) led to the kingdom being given to David
This event is a warning against the temptation to seek God through forbidden means when He is silent

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The use of necromancy, the meaning of 'the LORD has become your enemy', and the immediate doom pronouncement.
tips: Necromancy (seeking dead spirits) was forbidden in Israel (Deuteronomy 18:10-12) because it is a pagan practice
'The LORD has become your enemy' (v. 15) means God has turned away from Saul and his house, not that the LORD is personally hostile
The phrase 'the kingdom' (v. 18) refers to the entire nation of Israel, not just Saul's rule

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: When God is silent in your life, what forbidden means might you be tempted to use? How can you instead trust God's timing and provision?
tips: Consider an area where you are seeking answers through worldly means (e.g., social media, advice from others) when God is silent
Pray for the courage to wait on God without resorting to forbidden methods
Practice 'sitting still' in prayer for 10 minutes a day, as Saul did when he sought God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and ask for the strength to not seek forbidden answers when He is silent.
tips: Thank God that He has provided the true path (through the prophets and the Word) instead of necromancy
Pray for the courage to trust God's silence and timing in your current situation
Ask God to help you avoid the temptation to seek answers through forbidden means when He is silent

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Samuel 31:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the plea for death in verse 4 and the cultural context of the Philistines.
tips: Notice the phrase 'uncircumcised' (v. 4) which highlights the cultural divide between Saul and the Philistines
Pay attention to the desperate plea: 'draw your sword and kill me' (v. 4) showing Saul's realization of his impending death
The repeated action of falling (v. 4) and the armor-bearer's inaction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize the key events and characters in 1 Samuel 31:1-13 using the 5W+H framework (Who, What, When, Where, Why).
tips: Include the battle at Mount Gilboa (where)
Note the death of Saul's three sons and his armor-bearer
Describe the immediate aftermath: Philistines taking Saul's body and Jabesh-gilead's response

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Identify and explain the most impactful event or quote from 1 Samuel 31:1-13.
tips: Saul's plea for death (v. 4) shows his awareness of his failure and the cultural context of the Philistines (uncircumcised meaning non-Israelite) which he fears would lead to abuse
Saul's suicide is a profound act of self-sacrifice, reflecting his despair and the weight of his disobedience
Jabesh-gilead's loyalty (traveling all night) stands in contrast to the Philistines' display of victory, showing that the people of God remember their covenant with Saul

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to Israel through this passage?
tips: Saul's death illustrates the severe consequences of disobedience to God's commands (as seen in his failure to obey the Lord's call to fight the Philistines at Gilboa)
Jabesh-gilead's actions show that the people of God will remember their covenant and take steps to honor the dead who were loyal to God, even when the current leadership has failed
This passage serves as a warning about the cost of rebellion and the importance of the covenant with God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify and clarify 2-3 confusing elements in 1 Samuel 31:1-13.
tips: The term 'uncircumcised' (v. 4) refers to the Philistines being non-circumcised in the covenant sense, meaning they were not part of the covenant community of Israel
Saul's request for his armor-bearer to kill him is a sign of his despair and the realization that he is at the mercy of the Philistines
Jabesh-gilead's action of burning the bodies (v. 10) shows their commitment to the covenant and their refusal to let the enemy's victory take the bodies of their leader

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lessons from this passage to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on a time when you felt like you were in a position where you could not be 'uncircumcised' (i.e., without God's help) and how you might have needed to take action to avoid being treated as a f
Consider how you can show loyalty to God in your community, even when it's difficult (like Jabesh-gilead's action)
Pray for the courage to face the consequences of your disobedience without giving in to despair

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of this passage.
tips: Thank God for the lesson that even in defeat, His people can show loyalty (Jabesh-gilead)
Pray for the strength to face the consequences of our failures without despair
Ask God to help us avoid the fate of Saul by repenting and returning to Him
